div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of “Othello'' and of Ford's “Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

THE GREATEST care should be taken in what we eat and drink, yet we are too often in different and careless, notwithstanding health depends on what we eat and drink.

LORD CROMER’S SPEECH.

For the first time in her history Egypt has heard a great political speech. No other termm can he applied to the clear concise and weighty pronouncement made by Lord Cromer in reply to the address of the President of the Council of Ministers, and there are many recent political speeches that been termed great that suffer by comparison with Lord Cromer's words. True, we had expected that the last speech delivered by the retiring British Ageut and Consul General would be worthy of his reputation as a statesman and a scholar, but we confess that we are as surprised as we were delighted that Lord Cromer, in spite of his illness which had caused not a little apprehension among his more intimate friends, before the demonstration in his honour should not only have vanquished all physical obstacles but have achieved a notable oratorical triumph. His speech was notornate but its every sentence was pointed and polished as a rapier. There was none of the frills and furbelows of the platform : whether reviewing the careers of great Egyptians of the put or dealing with the problems of the future every word told, and when Lord Cromer the criticisms that have of late been lavished on his policy, by a vigorous counterattack, the happy combination of dignity, irony and wit, that has marked his previous speeches, did not fail him. He carried the war with a vengeance into his opponents' camp : we shall see what will he their defence against his vigorous assault. We have no doubt that a few members of the audience did not share the views expressed by the speaker and acclaimed by the

majority of those present. But they cannot fail to have been impressed by the greatness of the occasion and the importance of its cause, the personality of the leading actor in a historic scene and the enthusiasm with which some of the best elements in Egyptian society welcomed the chief captain of the forces of progress now retiring from the scene of his labors and triumphs. A statesman of ripe experience and proved courage, who had known the ruin of Ismail's days, the weary task of reconstruction that followed Tel el Kebir, the long agony of the Khartoum tragedy, the slow re-conquest of the lost land from barbarian oppressors, who had met representatives of the East and the West on equal terms in council or on the diplomatic battle field, addressed a gathering that felt more than a passing emotion to think that in two more days Egypt would see no more of the statesman who had re-created and enriched her. We do not deny the able assistance that has been rendered to Lord Cromer in the past by his colleagues and friends—many of whom we were glad to see around him on Saturday night. No leader could afford to dispense frith the diplomacy of a Nubar, the courage of a Riaz, the technical knowledge of a Garstin, when these high qualities were placed at his service, famous words in the administrator's armoury. But history will recognise that the wielder of these weapons, the one man that could direct the workers of Egypt's regeneration was the officer of artillery who became Earl of Cromer and virtual ruler of Egypt—once “the little gunner” now "the Lord."

Our readers will find in Lord Cromers farewell to Egypt what we may describe as the “root of the whole matter,” the enunciation by a responsible statesman of the two great factors of the present situation of Egypt, the continuance of the Occupation and the control by the British Parliament of the general administration of the country with the continuance of the present system of Government. Friends and enemies alike will do well to ponder over this open and Unambiguous declaration. The former will be encouraged by it to Like a more optimistic view of the general state of affairs than has been recently the fashion : the latter will do well to remember that it may be accounted romantic and courageous to battle with feats but that common sense forbids the exhibition of great sympathy with those who, unfortified by faith, injure themselves in the vain attempt to move mountains. Moreover, we would urge tho critics in and out of Egypt of Lord Cromers policy and administration to remember that they and their criticisms are alike Lord Cromers creation. What would have been the fate of some of our most rigorous critics of to-day in Ismail Pasha's days? Exile to the Sudan or tho ruthless application of the grim maxim “stone dead hath no fellow.’ What would be the fate of an editor w ho criticised a Turkish Pasha of Egypt, with the virulence expended by a native journalist we might name on the British Occupation ? Banishment to the Yemen or the khanjar of a wild cherkess. Let them remember that the privileges and rights —free speech, free Press, free meeting—which the Western world battled and bled for 400 years, have been granted them through the representations of the great statesman whom they affect to regard as a tyrant and that the educated Egyptian regards these things as his unquestioned rights, and then —then let them speak of the “Tsar of Kasr el Doubara. But time will only emphasise the verdict of the historians of to-day and to those whom the future alarms we repeat the message of the great pro-consul “Be of good courage.” union, courage, and truthfulness, such is Lord Cromer's political testament to the heirs of his labour. Thankful for the great example he has shown his fellow country men, who wish him long life, health, and happiness in the mother country to which one of the most illustrious of her sons is returning after life of toil in her service and in the service of civilisation, progress, and humanity.
URBANORA.
THE ONLY
ANGLO-AMERICAN CINEMAfOGRAPH
IN EGYPT.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: The public farewell to Lord Cromer organised by the specially appointed International Committee, which was held in the Khedivial Opera House, Cairo, on Saturday afternoon, was in every way worthy of the great occasion^ and the committee are to be congratfilated on and thanked for having organised so thorough? ly a representative assembly. Every nationality was well represented, and throughout thci meeting sincere and immense enthusiasm was manifested by all. The ceremony was timed to commence at six o’clock, and some time before that hour those who had been able to secure tickets began to arrive. Lord Cromer, arrived punctually at six o’clock and as ha stepped upon the platforpi the band of thd Inniskilling Fusiliers played “God Save the King.” The Sirdar then called for tlired cheers for Lord Cromer and this was responded to with unbounded enthusiasm.. The front row of the seats placed on the stage were occupied by Lord Cromer, Sir Eldon Gorst,1 Mustapha Pasha Fehmy, and Count dei Serionne. In the second row were the Ministers, Advisers, Under-Secretaries of States, the: Sicdar, Major-General Bullock, and Riaz Pasha, while the back of the stage was occupied! by the members of the International Committee. In the stage box on the righthand side were Prince Hussein Pasha Kamel and the Princes Halim ; and in the left hand! stage box were Lady Cromer and Lady Gorst. with a number of ladies.
THE INTERNATIONAL COMMITTEE.]

We should like to mention with high praise! the very successful arrangements of the committee for which Sir Vincent Corbett, assisted by his secretaries, was mainly responsible. The Financial Adviser deserves the hearty thanks of the Public and the Press for the fact that crowding and confusiort were absolutely nonexistent at Saturday’s demonstration.
The following are the names of the members of the Comitd d’Honneur International, who organised the meeting : —

S.E. Mustapha Pasha Fehmy, S E. Riaz Pasha, S.E. Fakhry Pasha, S.E. Boutros Pasha Ghali, 8.E. Mazloum Pasha, S.E. Ibrahim Pasha Fouad, S.E. Abani Pasha, S.E. Saad Pasha Zagloul, Major General Bullock, Sir Vincent Corbett, Major General Sir R. Wingate, Herr Von Mold, Sir Malcolm Mclllwraith, M. P. W. Machell, Sir William Garstin, M. D. Dunlop, S.E. Chawarbi Pasha, S.E. Mahmoud Pasha Suleiman, S.E. Dr. Schiess Pasha, S.E. Mahmoud Sidki Pasha, Dr. Abbate Pasha, S. E. Anis Mohamed Pasha, M. Benachi (Emmanuel), M. Bichara Androus, M Carver (Percy), M. Cattaui Bey, S.E. J. G4 Chakour Pasha, Demerdache El Sayed Abdel El-Rehim, M. Eid (Georges) Emin Kassem Bey, M. Escoffier, S.E Eskandar Pasha, Fehmy M. Foster, Mr. Greise Wassef, S.E. Ibrahim Yehia Pasha, M. Karam T. Khaled Boy Loutfi, Baron Jacques de Menasee, S E. Boghos Pasha Nubar, M. Padoa Bey, M Peliweus W. Habib Bey Pharaon, S.E. Idris Bey Ragheb. M Ricard, M. Rostowitz Bey, M. Rothacker ()., M. Rowlatt, S.E. Saha Pasha, El Cheikh Abdel Kerim Salam, M. Michel Salvago, Morcos Bey Semeka, le Comte de Serionne, Aly Bey Serour, M. Michel Sinadino, S E Ismail Pasha Sirry, M. Luigi Stagni, M. Adolf Stress, M. Raphael Snares. M. le Juge Tuck, M. Christophe Tschndi. .
COUNT DE SERIONNE’S SPEECH
The first speech was delivered by Count de Serionne, who spoke inFrench to the* following eff ect:—

My Lord — The Committee of Honour, formed since^the day following the announcement of your vLordship’s approaching departure, represents, without distinction of nationality or residence, all those who, united in a deep feeling of regret and gratitude, desire to express to you with all sincerity the grief which they experience in witnessing you, for reasons of health, cut short a career closely associated for nearly thirty years with the establishment and realisation of every kind of progress, such as the prosperity of Egypt bears testimony to. His Excellency Mustapha Pasha Fehmy will address you in the name of the natives and the officials of the Egyptian Government As for me, I have to express to you, in the name of the Committee, whom I thank with all my heart for having entrusted to me this signal honour, the feelings of those who, without being attached to this country by bonds of nationality or officialdom, heartily testify tb you their regret and their gratitude.

It is not for me, gentlemen, to enumerate at this time the numberless services which Lord Cromer has rendered to this country since the day when he was called to collaborate in it§ administration as Commissionner of the Public Debt up tb the very hour at which he leaves us, surrounded/by a respectful admiration a thousand times more eloquent thah all the words which I could use in retracing a career which belongs to history It is not that I would feai, in recording the important acts which have marked Lord Cromer’s mission in Egypt, to go beyond the lines which have been traced for me Those in whose names I speak have profited, equally with the local subjects, by the infinite progress which makes this country one of the most prosperous regions of the world, and probably the most hospitable. It is their - right and duty, therefore, to associate them- selves with those who recapitulate to-day,

as a measure of their gratitude, the acts of a career made wonderful by the unity, intensity, an^ efficacy of the effort expended. I will not, however, enter into the details of the measures 'of every kind due to the prudent counsels of Lord Cromer, • which have, as we all know, gentlemen, permitted foreigners resident in this country to participate so largely in its prosperity, jn an atmosphere of safety and tolerance, the equivalent of which it would be difficult to find in other quarters of the Globe.

div.head: The Capitulations
div.p: Allow me, however, to allude reservedly to the great conception of a new organisation which Lord Cromer leaves to be carried out. You would, certainly, my Lord, be pleased that I should allow myself, unofficially and in no spirit of adulation, which would contrast strangely* with the ready sincerity W my words, to tell you that the various ^colonies of Egypt unreservedly hope for the (realisation of your views in this matter. But /what, at least, I feel myself fully authorised to declare is how much all of us, without excep-’ Uion, have been touched by the care with which ^ ou have, in preparing the project to which 4 refer, consul ted the wishes of the greatest humber; how greatly. you* have impressed {Europeans in this matter that it is your desire };o work with them for the more complete ^melioration of their material and moral standing.

$ Fear nothing, gentlemen, I will not trespass further upon a ground touching, whether one wills or not, on high politics. I do not forget that we are only met here, my Lord, to assure you, by a manifestation in which all ranks, jill classes, and all communities are united, at [lie moment when you are on the point of jeaving tlds beautiful land of Egypt, which /;ives so generously to man of its most precious treasures, that the intelligent and worthy gratitude is developed under a sun as bene-ficent as the products of the soil, offering to 4*ou in this hour, at once sad and sweet, the idlest harvest in which you could rejoice.

div.head: Lady Cromer.
div.p: Allow me also to associate with your name, lb qnr expression of regret and respectful Sympathy, the name of her who has so well Iteconded by her charm and her inexhaustible fjharity the necessarily severest qualities which Jjave been evident in your mission—a gracious Associate in the efforts which have each day li.eeii expended abundantly for the prosperity rif the country. I/idy Cromer will ever live in rtnr memories as the living imago of goodness, theessantly tending, as kind consolator, the jjpisery and the sufferings of the poor. It is to {j|er as much its to you that we address our Lushes from the depths of our hearts for the ^ establishment of ybur health. If such is {[ranted, yon will long enjoy the greatest Recompense whiRl^an be conceded to man on (iirtli, t.heJ^Rgnt of seeing in the serenity of theJ^Ught of seei pbur retreat the gi^in which yon have sown blooming in ripe harvest.

div.head: European Gratitude
div.p: $ Gentlemen, I have firirehed ; but Lord jfcomer will certainly allow me to add two p/ords only, at the risk of exceeding for a poment the established order of the pro- lamme I have just spoken in the name of J|ie committee which id constituted as I have -(ready indicated. My mandate is ended, 4it, however, my Lord, it appears to me that J would not have fulfilled in entirety my fission if I did not offer for the homage of bother committee, which has done me the reat honour of appointing me president. It is imposed of European notables of Cairo not dding aiiy official position, but it decided give preference to the manifestation which is organised after it had been constituted— manifestation more general, and more fitted offer the homage which is your due. I will |Cot, therefore, make in the name of this committee a second speech ; which would be but prepetition of that which I have just delivered (♦lie truth is one, and all the resources of fpetoric which I might apply to vary, more or less happily, the phrases destined to express dnr sentiments, would not be able to add to pose two words which are alone of moment i nd which you will always remember, (we fisk it of you, my Lord as we shall guard them 1lithfully in ours) regret and gratitude. If, however, I have abused my position of official Sitor in putting before you this private ,itiative, it is because it has seemed to me hat it would, perhaps, enhance the tribute Ihich I have been bidden to offer to you.

div.head: Entente Cordiale
div.p: My second word is more personal It seems to e my Lord that it would be impossible for e to conclude, after having spoken in the ime of those who have entrusted to me the ipression of their feelings, without expressing lie highest degree of pleasure that this honour iiould be confided to a Frenchman. It appears Ity me that I would be ungrateful if I did not | jiblicly say to my colleagues ot the committee Ijhich I represent, bow much I feel the delicate Intention which has dictated the choice of one R[TO should address a statesman of the foremost rtnk before those who have more efficaciously Wntribnted to what is so fittingly named the Entente Cordiale”.

div.head: LORD CROMER'S REPLY
div.p: Tie enthusiasm of the audience had risen to its utmost pitch, and amidst immense and prolonged applause Count de Serionne resumed bis seat. Lord Cromer then rose and replied (in French) as follows :—

Coup? and gentlemen : My only regret at this morr.ent is ndt to possess a sufficient knowledge of tlie beautiful French language to be able to express to yon in a fitting manner all the feeling of my heart. All the same I would ask you to believe, Count, that I thank you most rely, as much from my own part as from that of Lady Cromer, for the more than kind words which you have just uttered. What shall I say, gentlemen, to the welcome which you have so kindly given me by the flattering uh of Count de Serionne ? Words fail me.

I cat cnly say that it is to me a revelation to know that I have so many indulgent friends up to this moment. What touohes me especially, gentlemen, is that this meeting oan be considered, as I believe it to be, of a truly inter national character. I hope that I may be allowed to draw this conclusion from it: that notwithstanding the inevitable and very considerable difficulties which the position which 1 have occupied for twenty four years presents, I have not shown myself, in the opinion of several who are certainly able to form a sound opinion, to be a too bad internationalist. Indeed, gentlemen, I have always told lyself that it was my first duty to do my utmost to safeguard the interests of my own ceun :ry and of Egypt. I put Great Britain and Egyptrin the same category because I refuse to consider them apart. I uphold that, once well understood, the interests of these two countries absolutely identical. But, gentlemen, beyond my quality of Englishman or Anglo-Egyptian, I have never, I hope, forgotten that 1 am at the same time an European. The well-being of the numerous and important European communities in this couutry is an Egyptian interest and therefore a British interest of the first order. It is with the thorough conviction of the truth of this fact that I leave Egypt, and if opportunity and necessity arise I will not fail to raise my voice in its defence. In thanking you again, gentleman, from the bottom of my heart I beg you to excuse the brevity of these few observations ; I am shortly going to have the honour of expressing myself in English. *

div.head: THE PREMIER'S SPEECH
div.p: On the conclusion of Lord Cromer’s speech, which was most heartily applauded, Mustapha Pasha Fehmy, President of the Council of Mini.nters, rose and, speaking in French, said:—

My Lord : —Allow me to express to your Lordship, in the name of the Government and of the great majority of the Egyptian people, the sincere regret which your departure causes them—a regret all the keener in that your departiire i8 necessitated by the state of your health, sacrificed in the constant and excessive labour which your attachment to this country and your fervent desire to incessantly contribute to its welfare have imposed upon you. Egyp’; cannot forget, my Lord, that it is to the moat prudent counsels, to the help and supper: which you have given her, that she owes x transformation which evokes a general feeling of admiration. It is for history to tell and to appreciate all the progress realised by this country. I only wish to emphasise that the fellah has felt the benefits of the accomplished transformation, and has participated above all others in the general prosperity. By the raising of her moral and material condition she has been able to experience happy days. It is to this work, my Lord, that your name will be attached, and it is this which claims to-day and will always assure the sincere and deep gratitude of Egypt. Allow me also, to express our regrets to Lady Cromer, to her who, by her goodness and her charity, has gained the hearts of the misfortunate, to whom she has given relief and comfort and who has thus merited general gratitude. My Lord, you have ’sincerely loved our Egypt you have eonseorated to it the best years of your life ; we are then confident of the continuance , of that goodwill of which you have given such constant proof, and, in testifying to you our deep a,flection, allow us to consider you always s one of us.

div.head: LORD CROMER'S SPEECH
div.p: In reply to the Premier Lord Cromer

Your excellencies and gentlemen, I must, ask you to receive the remarks I am about to make with some indulgence. It is, indeed, a considerable effort for me, both morally and physically, to address you at all— physically, because I have to muster all my strength in order to do so ; morally, because I am fairly overwhelmed by all the great kindness which I have received, from all classes during the last few weeks, and because it costs me a very bitter pang to part finally with a country where I have so many friends, and with which all the incidents of my pulilic career, as well as the joys and sorrow! of my domestic life, have been close-ly connected for well nigh a generation of men. I am leaving, gentlemen, not for any political ieasons, but because the hand of time has begun to press hardly upon me ; because, after iri»rly half a century spent in the public

service, during by for the greater portion of which I have been working at high pressure) think I am entitled to a rest ; and because I feel that all the very important interests over which it is the duty of the British representative to watch in this country can better be served by the appointment of a younger man in the full possession of bis mental and physical vigour.

div.head: Lady Cromer's Work
div.p: Before dealing with other matters, I should like to say a few wonls in reply to the graceful allusions which both tlie Count de Serionne and the President of the Council have made to the lady who has been my helpmate, and which have touched me—and, I am sure I may add, her—very deeply. I might wax very eloquent on this theme, but, for obvious reasons, will exercise some control over my feelings. I confine myself to saying that, whilst I was listening to the two sjpeeches we have just beard, I felt a strong desire to change places with the speakers. I should have preferred to eulogise Lady Cromer, rather than to reply to very flattering remarks which have been made about myself. Petbaps I may take this opportunity of saying that one of the objects which Lady Cromer haw had most nearly at heart has been to assist/in common with other philanthropic ladies, in arresting the terrible infant mortality in this country. I venture to express a hope that thin work, which has been well begun, will not in future be neglected.

div.head: Lord Cromer's Coadjutors
div.p: Gentlemen, I am no|. going to dwell at any length on the history of the past, neither can I allude to all of those with whom it has been my privilege to co-op^rato in the creation of the new Egypt. I will only say that I have always felt that I have had much more than my share of public praise for whatever good has recently been done in this country. I could have effected nothing without the hearty cooperation of others—Egyptian and European,— my own countrymen anil those of other nationalities.

div.head: Mr. Findlay
div.p: Amongst these, I should like to say that none has done m0re useful work than Mr. Findlay, who, during my absence, has, of late years, acted for nrte under circumstances of somewhat peculiar difficulty. I do not doubt that, in tlie course Of the twenty-four years during which I have held my present post, I have made many mistakes, and possibly I may have incurred some enmities; but your presence here this afternonn is, I hope, a sufficient proof that I have also contracted many friendships. Let me add that I am particularly touched by the present of so many of my foreign colleagues, with whom, as with their predecessors, AI have always entertained the most friendly personal rela tions.

div.head: Khedive Tewflk Pasha
div.p: Although, as I have said, I cannot of all with whom I have co-operated, yet there are one or two personalities who come so vividly to my mind: on the present occasion that I must perforce mention their names. In tho first place, I should like to say a word or two of one to whom, in my opinion, the public have never,! as yet, done sufficient justice. I allude to the late Khedive, his Highness Tewfik PasBa. Gentlemen, I am not going to use the language of empty compliment, or to employ conventional phrases What I say, I mean. Tejwfik Pasha understood his country and his Countrymen well. He constituted an admirable link between the reformers, whose zeal he at times tempered, and the people, whose ultra conservative fears of reform he used his influence to allay. History will be unjust if it does not accord to Tewfik Pasha a somewhat important niche ii the Valhalla of oriental potentates. He did not himself take any very active part in the regeneration of Egypt, but he was wise enough to encourage and support those who were working for its regeneration.

div.head: Nubar Pasha
div.p: Another great figure of the past comes prom-inently to my mind on Uio present occasion. Gentlemen, those who are acquainted with the past history of Egypt, dpd who have also read my recent annual Repo^ will recognize that the proposals I have brought forward in connection with modifying the regime of the Capitulations are the natural complement of the great and statesmanlike work originally projected by Nubar Pasha

div.head: Riaz Pasha
div.p: would mention the name of another Egyp- ( am glad to see here Vo my old and trusted mtlemen, little or the part of the reformer. Ittian statesman, whom this afternoon. I allude friend, Riaz Pasha. G courage is now require* young Egyptian who was not so always. Isffiail Pasha had some very drastic methods if dealing with those who did not bow befo him. Nevertheless, some thirty years ago, I viaz Pasha stood forth boldly to protest agains the maladministration which then prevailed in fegypt. He was afraid to bell the cat j admired his courage, and though^at subsequent periods, I frequently diftered from my old friend and colleague, I have never ceased to iregard him with the
esteem-I might almost say the affection— which his sterling qualities so well merit.

div.head: The Prime Minister
div.p: What can I say of my valued friend, Moustapha Fehmy Pasha, with whom I have been for so many years on terms of intimate personal friendship ? In the first place, I can say that he is one of the most thorough gentlemen I have ever met in my life. Perfect loyalty, straightforwardness, and truthfulness have been conspicuous in every act of his life. In the second place, I can say that, in a quiet, unobtrusive manner, he has rendered the most valuable services to his countrymen. I feel that these very tew remarks scarcely do justice to his eminent qualities, or to the personal esteem in which I hold him ; but I have still much to say, and I must be brief.

div.head: Boutros Chall Pasha.
div.p: It has been a great pleasure to me to be associated for so long with the present Minister of Foreign Aftairs, Boutros Ghali Pasha, whose versatile intellect has been of the utmost service in solving many of the tangled ques- ‘ ins to which the special political situation this country so frequently gives rise

div.head: Saad Zagloul Pasha
div.p: Lastly, gentlemen, I should like to mention the name of one with whom I have only recently co-operated, but for whom, in that short time, I have learned to entertain a high regard. Unless I am much mistaken, a career of great public usefulness lies before the present Minister of Education, Saad Zagloul Pasha He possesses all the qualities necessary to serve his country. He is honest; he is capable ; he has the? irage of his convictions; he has been afruAed by many of the less worthy of his own countrymen. These are high qualifications. He should go far.

div.head: European Coadjutors
div.p: Of my European coadjutors, all I need say is. that I thank them all most heartily for the invaluable help and support which I have received from them, under circum stances of great difficulty. I cannot undertake to mention all their names, but if there he any whose names deserve specially to be cherished by the people of this country, they are, perhaps, Sir Colin Scott-Moncrieff, Sir William Garstin, and their able subordinates, who have given the Egyptians what they most of all require—water. And to these I may add the name of a distinguished Frenchman, M. Maspero, whose erudite researches into the post history of Egypt have rightly secured for him a fame which is worldwide.

div.head: Sir Reginald Wingate
div.p: Lastly, gentleman, I wish to say that part of my duties has interested me more than that connected wjth the Sudan. It will al ways be a source of pride and satisfaction to that I have i been associated with Sir Reginald Wingate and his zealous and capable coadjutors in the remarkable work of regeneration which has for some years past been proceeding in that country. .

div.head: The People's Gratitude
div.p: With the help of those I have mentioned, and many others, >re have, I think, in spite of many shortcomings, done a good piece of work here during the last quarter of a century. I am bften told that the Egyptians generally fail to show any great amount of gratitude for the benefits which I have unquestionably been conferred upon them. I do not know what their feelings are in this respect. A French philosopher once said something to this effect— I cannot quote the words exactly.

“Lorsqu’uu peuple a trop souffert e’est peine qu’il a la force de remercier ceux qui le sauve,” and assuredly the people of Egypt past times suffered grievously. Whatever may be their feelings, I refuse to bo reasoned out of what, if it he a delusion, is at all events noble delusion. I refuse to believe that the Egyptians, or at all events the best amongst them, do not recognize that it was the hand of western civilization, acting mainly, during the last twenty five years, tllrvsgh the instrumentality of England, that raised them from the slough of despond in which their lot was formerly cast, and pointed out to them the way which leads to material prosperity and to moral elevation of thought. And if, which far from being the case, I were convinced that the present generation does not recognize this manifest truth, I should still cherish the hope that their posterity will do so. I believe it is a fact that the ch Idren of the blind are able

div.head: Two Principal Objects
div.p: Gentlemen, when try to occupy my two principal objects to myself, and which long term of years, other was admiDisl I first came to this couK present position, there were u>cts which I set before I steadily pursued for a One was political; the itive.

div.head: L'Entente Francaise
div.p: The main political object I kept in view was to contribute to the restoration of that good understanding between France and England udiich the force of circumstances, rather than any intentions or ambitions on the part of the rulers of populations of either country, had

impaired. That very distinguished statesmen, M. Gambetta, whose masterful iriil during the period he was in office exercised an abiding effect on the course of Egyptian history, otice said to his countrymen, “Ne rompez jamais avec l’alliance anglaue." My creed in international politics, which is, I believe, shared by a large number oL-iny couibtrymen, may almost be summed up in the {phrase, “Ne rompez jamais avec l’entente frta^aise.” This entente, to which Count de Serionne has alluded in sympathetic terms, • is lwwod on common interest^ on close neighbourhood, on community of political institutions, on the mutual respect acquired by past rivalry in on many a well-fought field, and on a recognition of the fact that the characteristics and qualities of the two nations serve as a complement to each other. Further, itthi?fctens le ; it is based on a common desire to maintain the peace of the world. If ever there were two nations marked out by the force of circumstances to be friends, they are certainly France and England.

div.head: The Rankling Sore
div.p: Well, gentlemen, it was clear; to the merest tyro in diplomacy that, so long as this Egyptian sore continued to rankle, that, friendship would necessarily be impaired; Therefore,when I came to Egypt in 1883, 1 determined, so far as the limited sphere of my action enabled to do so, to use my utmost endeavours to repair the breach. It was a long, uphill work. For years the two natioils looked at each other askance—comme chu\r chunt de faiencet os our French friends would say. We exchanged some hard, but fortunately, only verbal knocks. I came in (for my fair share of them. There was a time vhen my name rarely mentioned in a French newspaper without the addition of some rather uncomplimentary epithet, of which, I think, “ le brutal Cromer ” was that which was most commonly used. Indeed, if I remember rightly, I was on one occasion likened to the most bloodthirsty of heathen gods. I was termed Moloch. These journalistic amenities, which give zest and life to political discussion, need not be taken too seriously, more especially as they are now, happily, things of the past. Recently, I have been on more than one occasion termed, “ cet illustre vteijlard, ’’which clearly denotes a change of tone.

div.head: A Happy Day
div.p: Seriously, however, gentlemen, 1 did my best for many years to lead up to an understanding between the two nations, and I may say that one of the happiest days of my Egyptian career was April 8th, 1904, when the Ang?o-Frenth Agreement was signed. I do not> of course, r one moment, claim to have boon one of the principal authors of that Agreement. The chief merit of its conclusion lies with the statesmen w|io conducted the foreign affairs of either country, in Paris and in London, and also, 1 trust I may be allowed to add without dis-respect, with tlie talented sovereign whom I have had the privilege to serve. But I think 1 may go so far as to say that the continuous efforts made, by all concerned, in Egypt, over a series of years, to avoid unnecessary friction, and to deal in a frank and friendly spirit with any small grievances which arose out of the fact of the British occupation of Egypt, payed the way to a settlement, and facilitated the work of the negotiators.

div.head: Autocracy and Tyranny
div.p: I turn now to the administrative object which I have always kept in view. I have recently been hearing a good deal of wild talk about the autocratic and tyrannical government of Egypt. I do not care to! answer criticisms of this sort at any length. I may, however, say that throughout my Egyptian career I have done my best to until, a liberal spirit into a system of government which was of necessity bureaucratic. I have certainly | always endeavoured, to the best olj my ability, to ascertain the true state of public opinion, whether European or local, and to givo due weight to it I must leave it- ffir others to decide how far I have succeeded.

div.head: Egypt's Moral Advancement
div.p: I turn to another point I hear t frequently stated that, although the materit|l prosperity of Egypt has increased raarvelloUsly of late years, nothing has been done towards the moral and intellectual advancement of the people. What!, gentlemen, has there been no moral advancement? Is the country any longer governed, as was formerly the casrt, exclusively by the use of the whip ? Is not forced labour a thing of tho past ? Has not the accursed institution of^ slavery practically ceased to exist ? Is it not a fact that every individual in the country, from the highest to the lowest, is now equal in the eyes of the law R’, that thrift has been encouraged, and that thu most humble member of society can reag tho fruits of his own labour and industry ? ^hat justice is no longer bought and sold ; that every one is free—perhaps some would think too free—to express his opinions; that King Backsheesh has been dethroned from high plures and now only lingers in the purlieus and byivays of tlie administration ; that the fertilising water of the Nile is distributed impartially to prince and peasant alike; that the sick .man can be tended in a well-equipped hosjMal; that the criminal and the lunatic are no linger treated
